vectorData.altText: H10   Histology of the Anterior Pituitary
The anterior pituitary (AP) is composed of three subdivisions, the pars distalis (PD), pars tuberalis (not shown) and pars intermedia (PI). The posterior pituitary is also shown here (PP).

The pars distalis forms the bulk of the anterior pituitary. It consists of cords of endocrine cells that surround fenestrated capillaries, embedded in a reticular fibre stroma. The parenchymal cells of the pars distalis are categorized as chromophils or chromophobes, based on their staining characteristics.

Chromophils contain cytoplasmic granules composed of their cell product. Based on their affinity for acidic and basic dyes, they are subclassified as either acidophils or basophils, respectively. Acidophils fall into two categories, somatotrophs and lactotrophs, which produce and secrete growth hormone (somatotropin) and prolactin, respectively. Basophils are categorized as either thyrotrophs, corticotrophs or gonadotrophs, which produce hormones that act on the thyroid gland, adrenal cortex and gonads, respectively. Somatotrophs are the most abundant cell type, thyrotrophs the least abundant. Chromophobes lack granules, and therefore stain weakly. They include degranulated cells and stem cells.

The pars tuberalis surrounds the infundibulum.
The pars intermedia borders the posterior pituitary or pars nervosa. It is characterized by the presence of colloid-filled cysts derived from the lumen of the hypophyseal pouch. It is uncommon, but possible, for Rathkeâ€™s cleft cysts to become symptomatic.
Chromophils stain strongly with H&E. Acidophils (A) stain pinkish-red, basophils (B) stain bluish-purple.
Chromophobes stain weakly with H&E and do not secrete hormones.
The PI is characterised by the presence of cysts (C) derived from Rathkeâ€™s cleft.
